attributes.comment:
SEIU represents immigrant workers who perform some of our most needed, yet
undervalued, work ? work that is essential to our economy, families, and
communities. These hardworking immigrants care for our children and aged, cut
our grass, and clean our toilets. With dignity, they struggle to make ends meet
and sustain their families.

This is why Service Employees International Union strongly condemns the drastic
increase in the naturalization fees proposed by the United States Citizenship and
Immigration Services (USCIS). This proposal is ?another barrier?' for immigrants to
earn U.S citizenship and make the American dream unattainable. The fees for
starting the naturalization process will go from $400 to $675, an increase of 69%.
This new price tag constitutes a burden unfairly placed on the back of the poorest
immigrant families in our country.

According to the USCIS, this increase would pay for major infrastructure
investments and process enhancements that would be used to fix the broken
immigration system.

Service Employees International Union acknowledges that the USCIS does need
to make major investments to enhance the delivery of its services, and
understands that USCIS faces serious fiscal problems. However, we believe that
our system for funding immigration services should be a partnership where
applicants pay a reasonable fee for quality service. Therefore, we join our
community allies, and urge the President and Congress to address the USCIS?
fundamentally flawed system of financing immigration services by providing
appropriations to cover costs of major USCIS expenses such as infrastructure
investments, process enhancements and capital improvements.

This country is built upon the great tradition of the melting pot that welcomes and
assimilates new arrivals. The USCIS? proposed fee increase violates this legacy.
Immigrants who apply for naturalization are eager to demonstrate their
commitment to this country. It is counterproductive to raise the fees so high that
eligible immigrant families are excluded from full participation in our civic life.

# # #

With 1.8 million members, SEIU is the fastest-growing union in North America.
Focused on uniting workers in three sectors to improve their lives and the services
they provide, SEIU is the largest health care union, including hospitals, nursing
homes, and home care; the largest property services union, including building
cleaning and security; and the second largest public employee union.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Ali Jost, Service Employees International Union (SEIU)
